Entries.default:
Aloth's fingers fidget with the hem of his outfit, and his mouth is pressed into a thin frown.

He gives you a familiar, uncertain look as if he's trying to figure out what to say.
"For whatever reason, [Player Name], the gods have decided to trust you with the fate of the world." Aloth's eyes are fixed on you, his face drawn with grim determination.
"I must say, our adventures together have been a welcome change of pace." Aloth approaches you, looking more at ease than you've seen him in a while.
Aloth looks at you with a smile that suggests the two of you are in on a marvelous secret.
"What is it?"
"You seem troubled. Care to discuss it?"
"Keep it up and your face'll stay that way."
He relaxes a little.

"I hope you know I have immense respect for all you've accomplished." 

He purses his lips around the inevitable 'but.'
"But lately, I fear you're leading us down a troubling path."

"But lately, you don't seem to recognize the gravity of the situation before you.

"That troubles me."
"What do you mean?"
"What do you mean?"
He sighs.
"Please, I need to be candid with you."
"I took it over in hopes of changing all that."
"And that's why I set about ending it."
"Yet recently, I've seen you put entirely too much faith in old ways of doing things."
"Chasing Eothas and treating with the leaders of Deadfire has put you in a position of incredible responsibility."
"Or unconcerned by them." His expression darkens.
"What are you asking of me?"
"Don't lecture me. Ever."
"I appreciate your candor, Aloth."

"We both know the choices before us aren't always clear or simple. 

"I only ask that you give them due attention."
"The leaders of nations and powers listen to you. The gods themselves rely on you."
"I must admit, after receiving so much advice from you, it feels strange to be on the other end of things." He cocks his head thoughtfully.
"I've got to do what I feel is right. I hope you can respect that."
"I don't owe you any explanations."
"Like I said, you've misunderstood me. I do take this seriously, even if I don't express it the way you expect."
"I'll do my best, Aloth."
"No more than any of us can do."
"You're wrong. Kith need the comfort and structure of tradition more than ever."
"These things are traps, [Player Name]. Nothing more."

He sighs. "If nothing else, I appreciate that you've taken the matter to heart.

"Thank you for hearing me out."
"Perhaps I should know better by now than to take you at face value."
He nods. "Well, thank you for hearing me out. This is a great weight off my chest."
"Perhaps not, but what of everyone else? Those kith whose fates you decide?" His lips curl with distaste.

He freezes, shock plain on his face.

After a moment, cold detachment replaces it.
"Just consider it, [Player Name]." He turns away.
"Where are you going with this?"
"I didn't choose this role."
"I know that."
"You think I chose my Awakening? Or my responsibilities with the Leaden Key?"
[Listen.]
"No one made you take up Thaos' mantle."
"No one made you chase after the Leaden Key."
"You're missing the point! I was there, [Player Name]. That made it my responsibility."
"Just as Eothas, the Deadfire, and the rest are yours."
"You continue to rely on provincial assumptions. Cheap superstitions." His hands fly in wild gestures.
"You continue to act as if you're beholden to no one."
"Perhaps that seems trivial, but consider where blind reliance on tradition has led."
"Take the Gullet. A squalid slum, and all because Huana custom separates the castes."
"I told you about the bloodletting in Old Vailia, yes? Generations of suffering, and all for reasons no one even understood."
"You saw the Wahaki. They became a paranoid, isolated little tribe because none of them thought to question their hatred of outsiders."
"Or do you think Bearn and the others would have followed Gaderian Bosc if not for their unquestioning faith in Eothasian tradition?"
"Back in the Dyrwood, even you admitted Sagani's search for her elder was a waste of five years."
"Surely you can recognize what a danger this is."
"You're wrong. Traditionalism can be beneficial, too."
"I'm making the best decisions I can. You should know how hard that is."
"Funny, I don't remember the gods sending you to find Eothas."
"Enlighten me." He crosses his arms.
"I suppose I do." He sighs.
"I beg your pardon?"
"I like you, Aloth. But I need you to trust me and follow my lead."
"Whether or not you agree with my decisions, you need to respect them."
"I don't want to hear any more about this from you."
"Then you shan't." He turns away, fuming.
He's silent for several seconds. After a while, he nods.
"I suppose you're right." He sighs.
"I can't make your decisions for you. But I do hope you'll take my warning to heart." With that, he turns away.
"The Pr√≠ncipi have survived as a floating nation because of their shared culture."
"You're being just as dogmatic as you've accused me of being. Rejecting tradition on principle is no better than relying on it."
"Sagani's customs led her to us and shaped her. She found meaning in them."
"The Gullet is a mess because foreigners have driven so many Huana there. In the villages, the caste system creates community."
"I didn't mean to imply- er, never mind." He blanches.
"The Dawnstars' traditions have held them together here. Bosc's cult is the exception."
"Look, it works for some people."
"I hadn't thought of it that way." He pulls a sour face.
"I suppose that's true." He frowns.

"Perhaps it's not as simple as I'd thought.

"Still, I hope you'll take my warning to heart." He turns away.
"Yes, and it makes them ignorant and complacent."
"But, like it or not, you are responsible for the lives that have been placed in your hands."
"You can't shrug this off."
"You're right. I'll try to be more mindful."
"You expect me to carry the weight of the world when you can hardly bear your own burdens?"
"Or else what?"
"Surely I've earned more consideration than that." He scowls.
"I can only handle so much. Right now, Eothas takes priority."
"That sounds like something Thaos would have said."
"I beg your pardon?"
"Surely that's not the same. Thaos was a madman." Yet doubt has crept into his eyes.
"He also believed the gods had put him in a position to decide the fates of kith."
"Even Thaos thought he was doing good. That's why I hesitate to assume these responsibilities."

He looks at you for several silent seconds, deciding whether or not he believes you.

At last, he sighs.
"Do you?" His nostrils flare.
"What made you think of that?"
"Thanks, Aloth. I appreciate your company, too."
"Careful, or you're going to make me blush."
"We work well together."
He laces his fingers together as he considers your question.

"When we first met in the Dyrwood, you were struggling for your sanity. Now, you're fighting for your soul."

He pauses.
"I can't imagine the weight of that burden. And yet you've borne it - and more - remarkably."
"It's not as though I have much choice."
"Things have gotten dire, but I won't let that get me down."
"Thanks."
"But you do." His expression brightens with sudden emotion.
"That's precisely what I mean." His expression brightens with sudden emotion.
He laughs. "You know what I mean."

"That we do.

"But it's more than that." He laces his fingers together, considering his words.
"You seem to be holding up pretty well, yourself."

"I'm glad it appears so.

"Though I'm hardly in the same position as you." He gives you an almost pitying smile.
"Then I've fooled you!"
He chuckles. "And Berath herself, I imagine."
"That puts you in a position of incredible influence."
"I've known you to be a person of rare kindness." He gives you a warm smile.
"I've known you to be a person of strong principles." He gives you a warm smile.
"You often seem... indifferent to what happens around you." He squints thoughtfully.
"I've always known you to be thoughtful and deliberate." He gives you a respectful nod.
"I've known you to be... forceful at times. Hot-headed, even." He gives you a quick smile.
"It is sometimes difficult to gauge what truly matters to you." He squints thoughtfully.
"I'm glad you don't take your responsibilities lightly."
"I have a duty to do right by the world."
"I merely think things through."
"I'm just making this up as I go along."
"Circumstances put me in a position to help others."
"Ultimately, what we do matters little."
"Is that what you think? I just like to keep you guessing."
"Perhaps so. But you must know how many lives hang in the balance."
"We all do. But so few of us are in the position to do so much."
"If only more people thought as you do." He sighs.

"At Sun-in-Shadow, you determined the fate of thousands of souls. I should hope you gave the matter due consideration."

He sighs.
He laughs uneasily.
"You might feel differently if it were your soul hanging in the balance."
"You do?"
"I didn't mean to be callous. It's just..." He squeezes his face into a frown, as if trying to wring the words loose.
"That's nice, but I don't want to discuss it."
"Very well."
"Glad one of us does."
"I'd rather not talk about it."
"Me, too."
"I'm so rarely sure of anything, not the least when it comes to the grand affairs of gods and kith."
"I admire that."
[Listen.]
"My instincts point me in the right direction."
"I just try to do right by as many people as I can."
"It's just a matter of thinking things through."
"Everything comes down to being truthful."
"I tackle every problem with as much fight as I can muster."
"Nothing lasts. It's easy to be decisive when you remember that."
"That's precisely what I mean." He claps his hands together.
"I don't know that I could trust myself with the decisions you're making."
"I'm not as certain as you seem to think."
"Perhaps what I mean is, if we must be caught between the gods and the Wheel, then I'm glad you're on our side."
"Come, now, you make this look easy." He rolls his eyes. He doesn't believe you.
"Thank you."
"And I'm glad you're at mine."
"Next time Berath summons me, I'm gonna let you put in a good word."
He laughs. "I gladly would."
"That means a lot. Thank you."
"Now, I hope you'll excuse me, but I really must review my grimoire." He clears his throat, suddenly self-conscious.
"If you say so."

"The gods have sent you after Eothas. And every power of note in Deadfire has their own plans for you."

He tilts his head.
"But I'm pleased to see that you don't take your responsibilities lightly."
"Still, I'm pleased to see that you don't take your responsibilities lightly."
"I hope you'll remember this in the days to come." He gives you a thoughtful nod.
"If only more people did as much." He sighs.
"Please, just... remember this in the days to come." He gives you a thoughtful nod.
"After all we've seen, how can you say that?" He looks at you sharply.
"For the first time in a long while, I feel truly confident in where I'm going. What I'm doing."
"With you, I mean."
"You and I are rather different."
"You and I have so much in common."
"You're bold. Brash. More like Iselmyr, I suppose."
"We both tend to keep matters to ourselves. With good reason, I'm sure."
"You're forward. Outspoken."
"We're both careful with our words. With good reason, of course."
"We both think before we act. A sensible habit, but frightfully uncommon."
"Perhaps that's why you're decisive where I'm uncertain. You know what must be done, and you don't hesitate."
"And yet you're decisive where I'm uncertain. Somehow, you know what must be done, and you don't hesitate."
"But you always seem so certain. Somehow, you know what must be done, and you don't hesitate."
"My own brief tenure with the Leaden Key has taught me there's nothing enviable about the position you're in."
"My own brief time hunting the Leaden Key has taught me there's nothing enviable about the position you're in."
"What are you getting at?"
"Believe me, I'd rather not bear this burden."
"It's a welcome challenge."
"You give yourself too little credit."
"And yet you've borne it well. That's what duty is, isn't it? Simply doing what must be done."
"I'm glad you find it so. For few would be up to it."
"Whatever my faults, a lack of self-awareness is not among them."
The corner of his mouth twitches with poorly-concealed pleasure.
"Whatever works for you, I suppose." He frowns in confusion.
"Thaos relied on people's unquestioning trust in order. Their enslavement to tradition."
"Whatever this is, I don't want to hear it."
He sighs.
"Very well."
"Speak plainly."
"Speak plainly."
"That's how he built the Leaden Key into an organization capable of influencing events across Eora."
"You have a responsibility to use these opportunities to free kith from destructive habits and antiquated customs."
"I only wish you took your role more seriously. It so often seems you're oblivious to the lives that depend on you."
"You've misunderstood me."
"I do hope so." He rubs his brow, looking exhausted.
"At least I know where we stand." He turns away.
"Perhaps. But I can't fix everything that goes wrong."
"Of course not. I only ask that you do what you can."
"That may be."
"I couldn't agree more."
"I'm relieved to hear it."
He winces.

"I know I expressed my doubts about you earlier.

"I take them all back, [Player Name]." He looks to you, hopeful and apologetic.

"Earlier, I told you how confident I felt in your sense of direction. How you've borne your burdens."

He purses his lips around the inevitable 'but.'
"You have my full attention, Aloth."
"You have my full attention, Aloth."

"As a priest, this may be difficult for you. Tradition and liturgy are in your blood, I expect.

"But these things can be a crutch."

"I understand you monks are often bound to your customs.

"But they can be a crutch."

"You left your home because you rebelled against the establishment. 

"So it surprises me to see you cling to it here."

"I know you to be thoughtful. Logical.

"So it surprises me to see you cling so reflexively to old customs now."
"You were a historian. Surely you've seen the dangers of clinging to the past."

"Your old profession in the sciences surely taught you the value of logic over intuition.

"So it surprises me to see you cling to nostalgia and custom."
"You're probably not accustomed to being in a position of authority. After all, you left your homeland because you rebelled against the powers there."
"I suspect you may have an... uncomfortable relationship with authority." He grimaces, rubbing his knuckles. He's trying to tread lightly.
"Neketaka may be divided, but its people look to you."
"I know you have a troubled past. You've learned to look out for yourself, and you're accustomed to going where the wind takes you."
"Nevertheless, chasing Eothas and treating with the leaders of Deadfire has put you in a position of incredible responsibility."
"I know you care deeply about a great many things. You're certainly not shy about expressing it." A tired smile appears and vanishes just as quickly.
"You're often so careful with your words. It surprises me you could be careless in other regards."
"You have a good heart. I've seen you follow it more than once."
"You grew up with status and privilege. Perhaps you never bore the responsibility that comes with rank."
"You're truthful and straightforward, and I admire that."
"You may not be held in the highest esteem in Neketaka, but whether its people like you or not, you have a duty to them."
"I can only hope you keep that in mind."
"You know, I think you like having someone to challenge."
"I beg your pardon?" Indignation flashes in his eyes.
"That's how you've always defined yourself - by pushing back against someone else."
"Never mind."
"Fye, Watcher, ye're getting his gaff now!" Mischief sparkles in Aloth's eyes as Iselmyr briefly surfaces.

He rolls his eyes and barks an angry laugh.

It's a little too loud.

"You think you've got it all figured out, don't you? 

"Well, perhaps you don't know me as well as you think."
"Maybe I'd like to."

"What?" 

It's as though you've just doused him with cold water. 

He stares back at you with his mouth slightly open, blinking in confusion.
[Kiss him.]
"I respect you. But we don't have to agree to work together."
"Come on, why did you follow Thaos' Leaden Key for so long? Or Iselmyr? Or me?"
[Wait.]
Iselmyr cackles. "Tell him, Watcher."

At first, he freezes. His arms come up as if to push you away. 

Instead, he grips the front of your outfit and pulls you closer.

You feel him battling with himself - or, perhaps, with Iselmyr - as he leans into you, his shoulders rigid against you.

Yet even as he presses his mouth into yours, even as he tugs you closer, his raised arms feel like a barrier between you.

It's difficult to say whether passion or anger fuels him.
At last, he pulls away, watching you guardedly.
"I'm a solitary man at the best of times, and this is a most unusual moment to form intimate attachments."
"We're good for each other."
"This is just fun. You need to learn to relax."
"Will you please just talk like a normal person for once?!"
"You're right. There's too much going on right now."
"Perhaps, but in what measure?"
"You might find this hard to believe, but you're not the first person to tell me that." He gives you a self-deprecating smile.
"It's hard enough sharing my head with one other person." He glances up with a flick of his eyebrows, as if Iselmyr were listening in.
"I've spent most of my life hiding parts of myself - my name, my identity, my Awakening - from everyone else."
"I'm not sure I can accommodate more."
"I understand."
"You'll never be with anyone if you let Iselmyr hold you back."
"Thank you."
"Perhaps one day, when this business with Eothas is all over." He shrugs. Uncertainty and regret crinkle the corners of his eyes.
He chuckles. "If she had her say in this, I wouldn't want for... intimate company."
"I'm not sure I know another way, [Player Name]."
"Can't you give it a try?"
"You don't have to. We can take things at your pace."

He sighs, glancing at a spot between his feet.

He looks exhausted.
"I'm sorry."
"Very well."
"Fine."
"There's just too much else going on right now."
He turns away, shaking his head.
He nods before turning away.
"Sorry." He gives you a self-deprecating smile.
"That's what I'm trying to say. I need time."
"...As you wish." He turns away, frowning in confusion.
"Forget I said anything."
"Prove me wrong."
"I don't have to, [Player Name]. I've got nothing to prove to you."
"Let's just drop it, all right?"
"An excellent suggestion." He storms away, scowling.

"I suppose you're right." He sighs. He looks exhausted.

And confused.
"Now, if you'll excuse me, I think I need a moment to myself."
"And you of all people are going to tell me about being overly combative?"
"And you of all people are going to tell me about being opinionated?"
"Yes, I'd say our pursuit of Eothas has left us with quite enough to handle."
"Well, thank you for this... diversion nonetheless." He smiles and quickly turns away.

"The gods have sent you after Eothas. The people of Neketaka look to you. And every power of note in Deadfire has their own plans for you."

He tilts his head.
"I really care about you, Aloth."
"I mean it. You're a good friend."
[Kiss him.]

You feel him battling with himself as he leans into you, his shoulders rigid against you.

Yet even as he presses his mouth into yours, even as he tugs you closer, his raised arms feel like a barrier between you.

It's difficult to say whether passion or anger fuels him.

At first, he freezes in surprise. 

But he returns your kiss. Slowly at first, but insistently.

His shoulders are rigid and his back tense even as he leans into you. One hand comes to rest on the hollow between your shoulder blades, and the other gingerly brushes the back of your head. 

He embraces you as though he is afraid to hold you too tightly.
When he pulls away, his eyes are full of questions.

"Well, that was... unexpected.

"But not unwelcome." A smile plays at the corners of his mouth.
"Now, I hope you'll excuse me, but I really must review my grimoire." He clears his throat, suddenly self-conscious.
His ears redden.
"Was that too much?"
"Then how about an encore?"
"No! Not at all." He apologizes a little too quickly.
He laughs, but there's an edge of tension in his voice.

"I've always been solitary by nature. 

"It's been a relief to let my guard down with you, though."

His lips pucker into a thoughtful frown.
"But?"
"I want you to open up with me, Aloth. Don't hold anything back."
"That makes me very happy."
He winces. "That's just the thing."
"And I've come to care for you."
"Then I hope you'll understand where I'm coming from."
"I've spent most of my life hiding parts of myself - my name, my identity, my Awakening - from everyone else."
"I'm not sure I know another way, [Player Name]."
"Don't lock your feelings away, Aloth. Take a chance on me."
"You don't have to. I just want to be with you as you are - whatever that means."
"I'm not talking about physical space, [Player Name]."
"I don't know where exactly our journeys will take us. Or what will happen when we find Eothas." He glances down at his clasped hands as if hoping to find the answer there.
"After living with Iselmyr for so long, I've come to value privacy. The space to think and reflect in solitude." He looks at you, gauging your reaction.
He clasps his hands together, thinking.
"I don't want to take that away from you."
"You don't have to close yourself off from me now."
"I should probably remind you we live on a boat..."
"I don't want to make a commitment to you that I can't honor. And I certainly don't want to deceive you about my intentions."
"And I will have to return to my work with the Leaden Key if we survive this ordeal."
"Then perhaps this isn't the right time for us."
"We won't make demands of one another. Let's just enjoy our time together - however much we have."
He smiles. "Yes, I like the sound of that."
He nods slowly. "Perhaps not."

"Still, I don't regret any time we've shared, [Player Name]. 

"I'm glad we spoke of this." His smile only flickers briefly before he turns away.
"Speaking of Iselmyr, how does she figure into things?"

"Think of her as an intrusive neighbor - not always present, but rarely far away.

"Still, she's the least of my concerns." He takes a breath, steeling himself.
He draws back a little, fidgeting with the fabric of his sash.
"My reticence isn't about you, [Player Name]."
He sighs.
"I'm sorry, [Player Name]. I can't do this."
